channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Swiss Museum Unveils 1,600 Works of Art Left by Nazi-Era Dealer
item.description: The collection, including paintings by Renoir, Cézanne, Monet, Manet and Gauguin, was squirreled away by Cornelius Gurlitt in a house in Salzburg, Austria.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Hildebrand Gurlitt in 1925, one of four Nazi-era art dealers allowed to buy and sell plundered art.

item.title: P. D. James, Novelist Known as ‘Queen of Crime,’ Dies at 94
item.description: A consummate stylist, the British author and baroness accumulated numerous awards for the 13 crime novels produced during her writing career.
item.dc:creator: By MARILYN STASIO
item.media:description: The mystery novelist P.D. James in 2010.

item.title: E.U. Parliament, in Nonbinding Measure, Calls for Breaking Up Google
item.description: While the vote poses no immediate threat to the company, it symbolizes the growing resentment in Europe toward the American technology titan.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Scotland Should Get Increased Powers, Including Over Taxation, Commission Says
item.description: Under new recommendations, the Scottish Parliament would set income tax rates and brackets, and the region would get a larger share of welfare spending and revenue from sales taxes.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Greeks Go On Strike Over New Austerity Measures
item.description: Thousands of Greeks walked off the job while government officials wrangled with international creditors over economic policy and a financial bailout.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Taipei Mayor’s Race Could Alter Balance of Taiwan’s Political Power
item.description: A victory for Ko Wen-je, a physician who has cultivated an outsider image, would be a sharp defeat for Taiwan’s governing party in a city considered its stronghold.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Ko Wen-je, who is favored to win Taipei’s mayoral election on Saturday, greeting supporters.

item.title: Deadly Attack on Indian Base Near Pakistan as Leaders Meet in Nepal
item.description: At least 10 people were killed in an attack in Kashmir, just as the leaders of India and Pakistan were exchanging pleasantries in Nepal.
item.category: South Asian Assn for Regional Cooperation
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Suicide Bomber Attacks British Embassy Vehicle in Kabul
item.description: The blast, which officials said had killed at least five people, was the latest in an escalating bombing campaign in the Afghan capital.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Bobby Storey, Veteran of Irish Republican Army, Detained in 1972 Murder
item.description: Mr. Storey, a prominent figure in the Sinn Fein political party, was questioned in Antrim about the abduction and killing of Jean McConville, a widowed mother of 10.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Court Orders Hong Kong Protest Leader to Stay Away From Cleared Camp
item.description: Joshua Wong, a student who is the best-known face of the pro-democracy protest movement, was arrested when the police cleared away a street camp.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Despite Cease-Fire, Ukraine Conflict Grinds On, With Deaths Mounting
item.description: The Ukrainian military says it has recorded 3,412 rebel cease-fire violations, while separatists accuse Ukraine of shelling the eastern city of Donetsk.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a Ukrainian militia walk past a house riddled with shrapnel.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Looking Past Africa's Turmoil
item.description: The perception of Africa as a collection of dystopian states and regions persists, but there are signs of a subtle shift.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Francis Fraser, Who Cashed In on His Cruelty, Dies at 90
item.description: Known as a British underworld enforcer and once suspected in as many as 40 deaths, Mr. Fraser turned his life of crime into a lucrative retirement by chronicling his own deeds in books and films.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN
item.media:credit: David Westing/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Francis Fraser, known as Mad Frankie, in London in 1997. Mr. Fraser, a career criminal, was suspected in up to 40 killings.

item.title: International Red Cross, Citing Numerous Crises, Plans Record Spending
item.description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said it needed a record $1.6 billion to confront humanitarian crises around the world.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Peter Maurer, president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, said the organization's record budget is a response to the changing nature of armed conflict.

item.title: 2 Indian Teenagers Thought to Be Murdered Actually Killed Themselves, Inquiry Finds
item.description: The country’s top investigative agency said that the girls, whose bodies were found hanging from a mango tree, had committed suicide and that no rape or abduction was suspected.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Dai Xiang’s Modern Take on a Classic Chinese Painting
item.description: The artist borrows the visual and conceptual framework of “Along the River During the Qingming Festival,” a 12-century painting, to produce a patchwork of vignettes of everyday Chinese society.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A scene showing fishermen demanding payment before handing over the bodies of students who died while trying to save drowning children.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Backs Extension of Nuclear Talks
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s opinion is crucial, as he has the final say over a potential deal.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Greek Navy Tows Disabled Vessel Carrying Migrants to Safety
item.description: An estimated 700 people were on the 250-foot cargo ship that is now anchored off the Aegean island of Crete, according to the official.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Stalin, Father of Ukraine?
item.description: His rule saw the formation of a land with a strong national consciousness, a legacy that Putin prefers to ignore.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN KOTKIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Civil Liberties in Peril Down Under
item.description: Press freedoms are under attack in Australia and New Zealand.
item.dc:creator: By RAYMOND BONNER
